labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Requirements for covering NIPC
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body:
In this issue, we can list the requirements we need to fulfill to cover NIPC via the instance information document. The following list is just an initial starting point that will be extended over the course of future discussions.


- [ ] Include an `instanceId` in the events contained in an event history?
- [ ] Include an `instanceId` action states?
- [ ] Clarify where to put context information such as the SCIM ID (currently, this information is placed in the `$context`)
- [x] Discuss and clarify how ~~`protocolMap`~~ `sdfProtocolMap` fits into the instance information concept
    - `sdfProtocolMap` does not include instance, but (ecosystem-specific) model information, therefore it does not have to be covered by this specification at all

It would also be great if @bbrinckman could give us direct feedback on what the proofshot format needs to work with NIPC and what potential requirements are.

issues.title: Take context into account when generating proofshot content
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body: During the ASDF session at IETF 123, it came up that the content of proofshot might differ depending on the context, for example for privacy reasons. This could lead to the omission of some qualities in the proofshot or different values that are assigned to them.

issues.title: Consider describing `offDevice` information with `sdfContext` quality
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body: For a potential alignment with the ETRI-Draft on `sdfNonAffordance`-Information, we should consider using a keyword such as `sdfContext` instead, that was one of the potential proposals made by @jungha-hong during the ASDF meeting at IETF 123. In a PR, we should update the examples with the potential new keyword in order to investigate how well it can cover our use cases and requirements.

issues.title: Consider specifying an SDF Protocol Binding in the draft
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body:
This morning, I had the idea that could adapt the structure of the proofshot documents for designing an SDF way for the specification of protocol bindings.

In the examples below, you first find a simple SDF model:

``` yaml
info:
  title: Example SDF Model that serves as a demonstration for a protocol binding.
sdfObject:
  smartlamp:
    sdfProperty:
      status:
        description: Indicates whether the lamp is on or off.
        type: boolean
        writable: false
      brightness:
        description: Indicates the brightness of the lamp.
        type: number
        minimum: 0
        maximum: 1000
    sdfAction:
      toggle:
        description: Toggles the status of the lamp.
```

That model is bound to CoAP resources via a protocol binding document (see below) that is quite similar to the proofshots we currently have defined in the instance-information draft (note the structure that replicates the one of the original SDF model as well as the `sdfBindingFor`).

```yaml
info:
  title: A CoAP protocol binding example based on a smartlamp.
  version: '2025-04-08'
  copyright: Copyright 2025. All rights reserved.
namespace:
  lamps: https://example.com/lamps
  coap: https://example.com/coap-binding
defaultNamespace: lamps
sdfInstance:
  smartlamp:
    sdfBindingFor: lamps:#/sdfObject/smartlamp
    sdfProperty:
      status:
        readProperty:
          - "coap:href": coaps://example.org/status
            "coap:method": GET # Could also be assumed the default
            "coap:contentFormat": 50
        observeProperty:
          - "coap:href": coaps://example.org/status
            "coap:method": GET # Could also be assumed the default
            "coap:contentFormat": 50
      brightness:
        readProperty:
          - "coap:href": coaps://example.org/brightness
            "coap:method": GET # Could also be assumed the default
            "coap:contentFormat": 60
        observeProperty:
          - "coap:href": coaps://example.org/brightness
            "coap:method": GET # Could also be assumed the default
            "coap:contentFormat": 60
        writeProperty:
          - "coap:href": coaps://example.org/brightness
            "coap:method": PUT # Could also be assumed the default
            "coap:contentFormat": 60
    sdfProperty:
      toggle:
        invokeAction:
          - "coap:href": coaps://example.org/toggle
            "coap:method": POST # Could also be assumed the default
```

Currently, the binding only contains `href`s, `contentFormat`s as well as the CoAP method that is supposed to be used with the respective resource. As the actual bindings are defined within objects of JSON arrays, it is possible to define multiple bindings for the same affordance. We would need to discuss whether these arrays should be able to contain multiple bindings to different protocols, or one protocol binding document should only contain bindings to a single protocol, with the ability to compose multiple documents together.

Also note that we would need to discuss the "operation types" to which we want to map the different operations that are possible for each affordance type. The example above is currently heavily influenced by Web of Things when it comes to the `op` types, but needs to reworked in that regard.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body:
- Reference reusable defintions (e.g., `coap:baseUrl`) via sdfRef
- CoAP URL path could go into NIPC's `sdfProtocolMap`, for example

issues.title: Refine the usage of the terms abstract/conceptual/neutral
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body:
Via PR #22 we are now using three terms when referring to the common instance-related message format, its role within the SDF ecosystem, and its relationship with SDF models. As a follow-up to #22, we should revisit the three terms and refine their usage within the document.

> one more word: abstract/conceptual/neutral. 
> Maybe we can actually describe the a/c/n format in these terms.

_Originally posted by @cabo in https://github.com/ietf-wg-asdf/instance-information/pull/22#discussion_r2553864092_

> are/can be
> abstract vs. conceptual

_Originally posted by @cabo in https://github.com/ietf-wg-asdf/instance-information/pull/22#discussion_r2553863164

issues.title: Disentangle "abstract" and ecosystem-specific identifiers
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body:
> Hmm (marker for food for thought):
> This says what specifically it is (an identifier for the Thing) and how it is represented in that specific ecosystem (as scimObjectId).
> Do we want to disentangle this at some point?
> Right now, a different ecosystem cannot detect that scimObjectId actually is an identifier for the Thing and from which ecosystem that is comint.

_Originally posted by @cabo in https://github.com/ietf-wg-asdf/instance-information/pull/22#discussion_r2553873891_

issues.title: Improve the names of the newly introduced concepts
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body:
In the thread under https://github.com/ietf-wg-asdf/instance-information/pull/22#discussion_r2558614735, we have been discussing different names for the four "archetypes" we now have in the document. Going forward, we need to evaluate whether there are better names than

- State Report
- State Report Update
- State Patch and 
- Construction Message.

Below, you can find the discussion @cabo and I had related to this topic:

> Maybe we could shorten the archetype names to "report", "delta", and, "patch". I haven't found a single-word synonym for "construction message" yet, though.

_Posted by @JKRhb in https://github.com/ietf-wg-asdf/instance-information/pull/22#discussion_r2557945761_

> Hmm. Maybe "Configuration" could work as a replacement?

_Posted by @JKRhb in https://github.com/ietf-wg-asdf/instance-information/pull/22#discussion_r2557949754_

> "report" and "delta/patch" are about what the message is, structurally.
> "configuration/construction message" are about what the message is intended to do, just as "delta" vs. "patch" are.
> The (structurally) same message could be reported as a delta and then sent on as a patch.

_Posted by @cabo in https://github.com/ietf-wg-asdf/instance-information/pull/22#discussion_r2558614735

issues.title: Associate identity manifest with the construction message arche type
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body: We are currently associating the identity manifest with the new status report archetype. This is actually incorrect as pointed out by @jungha-hong and should be fixed so that it is associated with the construction message archetype instead.

issues.title: Indicating construction parameters for affordances (via `sdfContext`?)
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body:
In the current revision of the draft, the way construction is supposed to be handled from an SDF perspective is still a blank spot that needs to be addressed going forward. One challenge in particular is the question of how we could integrate information relevant for the construction process into our now unified message format.

I think one way of handling this would be deviating a bit from the idea of using the exact same structure for the status report and construction message archetypes. Instead, we could let the affordance entries in a construction message provide arguments for the constructor parameters defined in a model, would could lead to instance-related messages like the following:

```yaml
info:
  messageId: 75532020-8f64-4daf-a241-fcb0b6dc4a42
namespace:
  models: https://example.com/models
  sensors: https://example.com/sensor
defaultNamespace: models
sdfInstanceOf:
  model: sensors:#/sdfObject/sensor
sdfInstance:
  sdfContext:
    ipAddress: 192.168.1.5
  sdfProperty:
    temperature:
      "$comment": This constructor argument sets the reported unit to Celsius
      unit: Cel
```

In this case, we could let an SDF model define that the temperature unit is be settable via a constructor parameter. In a state patch message, we could then refer to the same set of parameters to apply an update to the device and, for example, set the reported unit to Fahrenheit.

However, I am wondering whether this mechanism would actually go against our principle of separating class-level from instance-related information, since applying the unit to the `sdfProperty` definition would effectively create a derivation of the base model. This would effectively hand over control from the base model to the newly created one, which does not feel exactly right to me.

I am therefore asking myself whether we should treat configurable parameters as context information instead, by establishing a relationship between `sdfProperty` and `sdfContext` via something like the `contextMap` we already have in the draft. Then we could set the `unit` that is applicable to the `sdfProperty` `temperature` like so:

```yaml
info:
  messageId: 75532020-8f64-4daf-a241-fcb0b6dc4a42
namespace:
  models: https://example.com/models
  sensors: https://example.com/sensor
defaultNamespace: models
sdfInstanceOf:
  model: sensors:#/sdfObject/sensor
sdfInstance:
  sdfContext:
    ipAddress: 192.168.1.5
    temperatureUnit: Cel
```

The linking in the SDF model on the other hand could look like this:

```yaml
namespace:
  models: https://example.com/models
  sensors: https://example.com/sensor
defaultNamespace: models
sdfObject:
  sensor:
    sdfContext:
      ipAddress:
        type: string
      unit:
        type: string
    sdfProperty:
      temperature:
        type: number
        contextMap:
          unit: "#/sdfObject/sensor/sdfContext/unit"
```

This approach would have the advantage of having one model that fully controls all configurable parameters. In my opinion, it would also further justify having a separate `sdfContext` keyword, as only this information would be settable in a construction or state patch message.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body:
In the meantime, I also had to think about once again whether it would make sense to add another layer to instance-related messages and report actual values under a `value` quality. This would enable us to put construction parameters (in this example: `unit`) under the named qualities. Similarly, we could also include information such as timestamps.

```yaml
info:
  messageId: 75532020-8f64-4daf-a241-fcb0b6dc4a42
namespace:
  models: https://example.com/models
  sensors: https://example.com/sensor
defaultNamespace: models
sdfInstanceOf:
  model: sensors:#/sdfObject/sensor
sdfInstance:
  sdfContext:
    ipAddress:
      value: 192.168.1.5
  sdfProperty:
    temperature:
      unit: Cel
```

However, when it comes to construction parameters, this has the disadvantage of not providing the clear separation of instance-related and model-level information.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body:
TODO: Look at the approach chosen by Thing Models to define "variables"/"value slots" and what the mechanism for assigning values to them looks like

Need to look into how the various ways such a message can interact with entities such as digital twins, asset management systems etc. Different applications may be interested in different kinds of messages (or rather: *information sets* or *snippets*). (Also note the problem of access control that arises here.)

Also need to look at the actual problems/use cases we are trying to solve and come up with more examples.

The "purpose in life" aspect that came up during IETF 124 would also be covered by context information. Solving this problem would also bring us close to what we are actually trying to achieve here. There are different kinds of purpose in life information, a temperature sensor, for example, might not really care what it is actually being used for, to make use of the information the sensor collects other devices need to know in which room the sensor measures temperature.

The message (format) itself might be orthogonal to the actual usage of the messages (and questions like access control). This could also be relevant for understanding the relationship with NIPC, which is using SCIM in a similar way. Perhaps we can learn a lot here for construction messages as well.

State patches are stateful (by design) which implies the use of a protocol, but they may still be abstract enough to understand which changes are applied to the information at hand.

Provenance might be added later to messages. Note that there are different levels of quality(?)/"longevity" of context information – pieces of context information might be used as "variables", but others might not.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body:
TODO: Draw inspiration (but not too much) from YANG for and naming and using variables: schema nodes and data nodes 

Use examples to investigate whether we can map their _intent_ into our conceptual world.

issues.title: Revisit the `thingId` and `timestamp` qualities
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body:
Going forward, we need to deal with metadata such as the `thingId` and state-related qualities such as the `timestamp` more thoroughly. This includes the following aspects moved here from PR #29:

- Consider creating a separate metadata group
- Deal with the term "instance" and enable different types of instances to cooperate/integrate into one Thing

_Originally posted by @JKRhb in https://github.com/ietf-wg-asdf/instance-information/pull/29#discussion_r2709123463_

issues.title: Revisit Litmus Test
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body:
I had to think about the "litmus test" again with regard to the identity manifest, and was wondering whether construction messages could act as a means to initialize properties that are read-only. I think this might be a better way to handle identity information, as that kind of information can probably be retrieved via application-layer protocols in many cases and is therefore not really part of the context. Similarly, patch messages could be a way to change the value of properties that are otherwise non-writable during reconfiguration.

I think the situation with actions and events is probably different, although we could think about whether there are situations where you want to initialize a device with an action state, or an action or event history.

_Originally posted by @JKRhb in https://github.com/ietf-wg-asdf/instance-information/pull/29#discussion_r2688522285_

issues.title: Distinguish between "will to change" and the "embodiment as a message" in the terminology section
issues.author: JKRhb
issues.body: The terminology section needs to be updated to go beyond what we currently outline with regard to instance-related messages.

pulls.title: Update proofshot examples
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: This PR will eventually incorporate the feedback and discussions from the OneDM meeting on April 10, 2025, into the document.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body:
@mjkoster @akeranen Thank you once more for the very interesting discussion yesterday! Based on our results, I hope that I was now able to make the PR a bit more concise and improve upon the actual examples, so that an (initial) review should now be possible :) I will probably work a bit more on this over the course of the weekend, but any feedback is greatly appreciated already. 

Btw: You can find a diff of the rendered version [here](https://author-tools.ietf.org/api/iddiff?url_1=https://ietf-wg-asdf.github.io/instance-information/draft-bormann-asdf-instance-information.txt&url_2=https://ietf-wg-asdf.github.io/instance-information/adjust-examples/draft-bormann-asdf-instance-information.txt) and the rendered version in full [here](https://ietf-wg-asdf.github.io/instance-information/adjust-examples/draft-bormann-asdf-instance-information.html).

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body: The changes that have been moved to #6 have now been removed from this PR via cad0984.

I think this is now moving to "roads not taken".
We want to be able to use an SDF model to describe (constrain) instances; we probably don't want to make SDF models a meta-model of themselves...
The proofshot example shows actual values; the semantic information from the model (e.g., units, ecosystem-specific semantics) still applies but is not part of the proofshot (a reference to the model is).

pulls.title: Adjust construction examples
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: This PR extracts the construction-related adjustments from #5 into its own PR to better differentiate between changes to the proofshot and constructor examples.

pulls.title: Missing pushes
pulls.author: cabo

pulls.title: Add initial CDDL schema for SDF proofshots
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: This PR contains a first attempt at creating a CDDL schema for SDF proofshots. Due to some problems with the available tooling, I haven't been able to fully verify that the schema is correct and works as intended; also, there are still a couple of points that need discussion. Still, I hope that the schema will work as a starting point for further discussions.

pulls.title: Add example for proofshot deltas
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body:
This PR adds an initial example for a proofshot delta that refers to a previous proofshot via its ID.

All of this is still pretty rough, but it should enable further discussions regarding the proofshot delta concept.

pulls.title: Fix issues with CDDL proofshot schema
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: I am having some trouble to properly run the validation locally, but I hope that this PR resolves at least some of the issues we were observing with the proofshot CDDL schema that was added in #8.

pulls.title: Update "Roads not taken" examples to `I-D.lee-asdf-digital-twin-08`
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body:
This PR updates the examples in the appendix to version -08 of the digital twin draft to be more consistent with the examples from the main part of the document. This changes also enables us to remove the -07 reference in order to only have one draft version referenced.

Note that I had some small difficulties updating the examples, since the approach in -08 is still a bit inconsistent. However, as these examples only serve an illustrative purpose to begin with, I hope that the updates are fine (after a few adjustments, if needed).

pulls.title: Start specifying an action-based constructor approach
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body:
As discussed yesterday, this PR provides an initial example for an alternative constructor approach where `sdfAction`s are reused instead of introducing a new keyword.

There are still a number of aspects that require discussion here, but the PR should be a first step toward making a more informed discussion.

comments.body:
- [x] Move `target` under `construct`
  - Link to question: What model is valid here?
- [x] Remove `temperature` and required
- [ ] Use as basis for further discussion

One thing I noticed here is that the example is now rather a factory for models instead of documents related to instances (with the `ipAdress` being an exception as a piece of context information).

I guess the question would be what kinds of output we produce from the constructor – would it be an extended model and a proofshot? Or rather a mapping file and a proofshot?

```suggestion
Lastly, it is currently unclear what kind of schema information should be provided for the action's `sdfOutputData`.
As a return value, a pointer to the instantiated device and/or the models describing it could make sense.
```

pulls.title: Add rules for CDDL validation to Makefile
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: This PR takes over the code for validating the SDF models within the draft from the SDF Mapping repository.

pulls.title: Remove temperature and a redundant required indication from proofshots
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: Looking at the diff of the two latest draft versions, I noticed a couple of small mistakes which I wanted to fix with this PR. I also added a "DISCUSS" comment to the example for the proofshot delta constructor, which might not be that suitable as an example after all.

pulls.title: Model context and offDevice information via sdfContext
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body:
This PR contains a proposal for replacing and unifying the previous usages of `offDevice` and `$context` via an `sdfContext` quality (which is a potential replacement for the `sdfNonAffordance` quality introduced by @jungha-hong et al.).

Reading through the updated examples, I think this resolves some of the open questions in the draft document quite well and contributes to a cleaner separation of model and instance information.

When merged, this PR resolves #17.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body:
## OneDM Meeting 2025-08-20

- "Litmus test" needed
  - Collect examples for categories (location, information from asset management systems, model number/SKU, ...)
    - TODO: Should avoid the term "static" in this context
      - "Encoded in the document itself" – model vs instance? Need to cleanly separate the two types of information items
        - SDF model can control the shape of `sdfContext` via `sdfData`
    - Access Control needs to be modelled as well – not everyone should be able to find out a purchase order, for example
  - Provide guidance to make the decision on `sdfProperty` and `sdfContext`
    - Guidelines might be ecosystem-specific
  - Evaluate whether there are other aspects that are "hiding" in `sdfProperty`
- Evaluate how/whether WoT is expressing information similar to `sdfContext`
  - There might be no "native" way to do this in WoT TD yet
  - Talk to Ege/Cristiano about this, could become a topic in one of the next TD calls
    - "Identified the need for a uniform way for adding out-of-band information to a model"
TODO: Mark this as an Editor's note.

Thinking about the protocol map a bit more, I had the impression that it might actually be a good reference point for the Litmus test. Taking the IP address as an example, we could ask ourselves:

- Could the information be retrieved via a protocol from the protocol map?
- Is the information the basis for using the protocol map in the first place?

I guess with something like identity information, there is a gray area where you could model the information both as context information or a property.

Another aspect might actually be related to digital twin modelling, where you have information that needs to be provided to have an accurate virtual representation of a physical. So with the mount location for example, that is something that can only be changed by moving the device in the real world. So it may be obvious in the real world that a device is mounted to the wall, but to get an accurate virtual representation, this context has to be modelled explicitly.

Maybe this could be a second dimension of the Litmus test.

Another thought: Maybe we can differentiate between "internal" context information (provided by the Thing itself to be able to perform interactions) and "external" context information (provided by an external entity to capture the Thing's embodiment in the real world).

Then again, external context data will probably also include information from something like an asset management system or a SCIM database, so its use will probably still go beyond digital twins in the narrower sense.

> "external" context information (provided by an external entity to capture the Thing's embodiment in the real world).

This got me thinking that something like the dimensions of a thing or other information regarding its "casing" could also be interesting examples for context information to be modeled via `sdfContext`.

pulls.title: Experiment with `sdfRelation` for specifying constructors and parameter targets
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body:
This morning, I had the idea that `sdfRelation` might be a good way of linking constructors and their parameters to their designated targets without introducing new targets. This solution would also resolve the question of how to identify a constructor. The question of how to indicate a constructor _preference_ is still open, though.

This PR depends on #18 and should be merged afterward in order to decrease the diff size.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body: After working on #18, I am currently not sure whether this PR might have become obsolete by now. Therefore, I will mark this one as a draft for now that we could revisit after #18 has been merged.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body: As discussed with @cabo yesterday, the approach described in this PR has probably become obsolete in the meantime, which is why I closed it.

Regarding constructors, I had two additional ideas in the meantime:

1. We could simply model different constructors by offering different sets of `sdfInputData` parameters via `sdfChoice`. This assumes, though, that the output format would stay consistent (e.g., since we are only returning a pointer to the result).
2. The preference of constructors could also be modeled by using `sdfRelation`, although the details need to be discussed here – should there be transitive `sdfRelations` between constructors, with `sdfRelation`s between the “adjacent” ones? Or could we also have an `sdfRelation` with multiple `target`s and then apply a mapping of priorities to that?

pulls.title: Add `...` to end the YAML header
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: In my local editor, I get a strange ... syntax highlighting of the Markdown document, since my editor is not noticing that the YAML header has actually ended: This PR proposes to explicitly end the YAML header with an additional `...`, resolving the editor confusion (apparently without breaking the document).

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body: @cabo As the changes are pretty straightforward, I would go ahead and merge this one.

pulls.title: Incorporate results from and since IETF 124 into the document
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: This PR further incorporates the results from IETF 124 and the OneDM meetings that happened in the meantime into the document. The PR is currently still WIP – I will add more content later to establish a basis for further discussion.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body: As discussed with @cabo, we are going to merge this PR to be able to create a new snapshot (no pun intended) for the interim meeting next week. I've created the issues #23, #24, and #25 to capture the remaining unresolved comment threads, on which we can follow up in separate PRs.

reviews.author: cabo
reviews.body: Some initial comments (from typos to long-term background deliberations)

comments.body: If there is a concrete (JSON-based) representation, should we distinguish this from the "abstract" representation?

```suggestion
: A message that describes the state or a state change of a specific instance.
```

A bit more "specific", maybe

maybe

```suggestion
The instantiation of an SDF model does not directly express an instance, which is, for example, a physical device or a digital twin.
```

```suggestion
4. *Patch messages* that indicate state changes to *cause* a Thing's state to change
```
Maybe we should collect all subset/variant proofshots under that headline
Aren't the direct reports more different from the delta/patch messages, so we should distinguish direct vs. delta and then cause/effect within delta (and/or within direct reports!).
Some of it, yes.  The media type for a direct report will be different from that for a patch/delta, which could be the same media type or (more subtly) different again.
This may be the point to point out that this syntax describes an abstract structure (syntax) as well as a concrete syntax that may actually be used in interchange.
Should we make more use of "archetype" (introduce the term earlier)?
I think for now capturing this is more important than nicely integrating it, so we may not want to tend to this TODO right away

```suggestion
information, either in general or in a specific form such as a context snapshot etc.).
```
maybe move up "(class-level information)" to after *model*

are/can be
abstract vs. conceptual

one more word: abstract/conceptual/neutral. 
Maybe we can actually describe the a/c/n format in these terms.
We might mention that this sentence is not about the essence (information model) of instance-related messages; we are now into designing the actual format (data model).
We sure want to keep it; we need to fully grasp its consequences in due time first...

```suggestion
Distinct from SDF models are two instance-specific blocks, the first of which is identified via the `sdfInstanceOf` keyword.
```
For deltas/patches, should there be a media type (content type) somewhere?

Hmm (marker for food for thought):
This says what specifically it is (an identifier for the Thing) and how it is represented in that specific ecosystem (as scimObjectId).
Do we want to disentangle this at some point?
Right now, a different ecosystem cannot detect that scimObjectId actually is an identifier for the Thing and from which ecosystem that is comint.

Should this information be captured somewhere?
Right now it seems to be lost.
I do think it is quite important.
Good point! Upated via e3c9bbfe7bff1d6733d2e855ac6c599a5cc3e205

Good point, would the following work as a clarification?

```suggestion
The data model of instance-related messages makes use of the structural features of SDF models (e.g., when it comes metadata and namespace information), but is also different in crucial aspects.
```
Oh, definitely, that is a good point :) I suppose we need to discuss how many new media types we actually need (three?) to reliably distinguish the different message/archetypes.
Hmm, yeah, that is an interesting aspect – should we address that at the model level, maybe even via mapping files?
Thank you, I tried to recapture it via 1cf3f68549a2da59019b33445c2d4c5774dbfbf1

Thank you, I tried to amend the paragraph as follows based on your comment, let me know if you see room for improvement here:

```suggestion
{{{#syntax}}} specifies the formal syntax of instance-related messages all normative statements as well as the examples in this document will adhere to.
This syntax can serve to describe both the abstract structure and the concrete shape of the messages that can be used as a neutral form in interchange.
```

Would the following be an improvement of the sentence here:

```suggestion
The uniform message format serves as the basis for all three message types, which are distinguished via their media types as well as small syntactical differences.
```
Yeah, that is a good point actually! So maybe we need to add in another level of "branching out" the message types.
You mean identity manifest?

I guess that would make sense – the suggestion unfortunately cannot be applied here directly, but it would look like this then, right?

```suggestion
both Abstract (eco-system independent) as well as concrete (JSON-based) Representation formats ...
```

Two perspectives/requirements of the same abstract representation:
- _conceptual_ for the "model" of the messages
- _neutral_ (and concrete) for the actual interchange, ecosystem-independent but "real" ("red star")
Resolved via 594fb7b98e1d7cddd3f821644f79e62e637d446c.

- Two dimensions: Content and intended effect
- TODO: Add Table/matrix for categorization
Maybe we could shorten the archetype names to "report", "delta", and, "patch". I haven't found a single-word synonym for "construction message" yet, though.
Hmm. Maybe "Configuration" could work as a replacement?

"report" and "delta/patch" are about what the message is, structurally.
"configuration/construction message" are about what the message is intended to do, just as "delta" vs. "patch" are.
The (structurally) same message could be reported as a delta and then sent on as a patch.

pulls.title: Apply editorial improvements
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: This PR applies a couple of editorial fixes to small issues I noticed when rereading the document.

comments.body:
```suggestion
1. the intended effect of a message, which can either be a report or an update of a Thing's state, and
```

pulls.title: Add experimental section on linking sdfProtocolMap and sdfContext
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: This PR incorporates an experimental approach from the Hedgedoc that summarized the SDF-related results of IETF 124. There is probably still some refinement needed (especially in future versions of this document), but for now it will probably serve as a good basis for further discussion.

comments.body:
```suggestion
When using the `sdfProtocolMap` concept introduced in {{-protocol-map}}, sine protocols might need context information such as a hostname or an IP address to actually enable interactions.
```

pulls.title: Rework and refine document structure
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: Resolves #28 (eventually).

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body: @cabo This PR now evolved into a more comprehensive update to the document. I tried to reduce the redundancy a bit by integrating the concrete examples from the non-affordance draft and earlier versions of our draft into the four "archetypes", renaming them in the process. I hope that the updates point into the right direction, maybe we can also discuss them more comprehensively during the upcoming OneDM meeting.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body: @cabo I think this PR may now be ready for an initial review (also see [here](https://author-tools.ietf.org/api/iddiff?url_1=https://ietf-wg-asdf.github.io/instance-information/draft-ietf-asdf-instance-information.txt&url_2=https://ietf-wg-asdf.github.io/instance-information/identity-manifest/draft-ietf-asdf-instance-information.txt) for the rendered diff). The modelling of action and event histories still needs some discussion, which is why have not updated the CDDL in that regard, but overall I think the document *should* be a bit more mature now.

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body: I think with the latest changes, this PR can now be merged. There are probably still some aspects that need to be improved in the current state of the PR, but I suppose we can simply follow up with another revision after today's interim.

I had to think about the "litmus test" again with regard to the identity manifest, and was wondering whether construction messages could act as a means to initialize properties that are read-only. I think this might be a better way to handle identity information, as that kind of information can probably be retrieved via application-layer protocols in many cases and is therefore not really part of the context. Similarly, patch messages could be a way to change the value of properties that are otherwise non-writable during reconfiguration.

I think the situation with actions and events is probably different, although we could think about whether there are situations where you want to initialize a device with an action state, or an action or event history.
Move `timestamp` to the `info` block (and rename it?)

- Rename back to `thingId` 
- Consider creating a separate metadata group
- Deal with the term "instance" and enable different types of instances to cooperate/integrate into one Thing
Add a note that the terms "context snapshot" and "proofshot" are used colloquially here (for now).

pulls.title: Reflect WG adoption in source files
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body:
Since the adoption call for this draft within the ASDF WG has ended with no objections, this PR prepares the document to be reposted as a WG document.

Note that although the chairs have stated that the deadline has passed without objection, the draft has not been officially adopted yet. So merging and reposting to the DT should wait until an official announcement has been made (CC @mcr).

comments.author: JKRhb
comments.body: I took the freedom of merging this PR after receiving another confirmation by the WG chairs.

pulls.title: Include message "archetypes" in terminology section
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body:
This PR updates the terminology section by including the missing message "archetypes" and rewriting the existing "Proofshot" entry to fit the latest changes to the draft.

There might be room for improvement, so I am looking forward to your feedback!

comments.body: incurrencies?

Ahem, I think I wanted to write “inaccuracies” here 😅 


```suggestion
  inaccuracies could occur while capturing the affordance state.
```

pulls.title: Use RFC 9880 instead of the I.D. for SDF Base
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body: This PR updates the SDF reference after the recent publishing of RFC 9880 ( :tada: ).

comments.body:
Need to change here, too:


```suggestion
This document specifies instance-related messages to be used in conjunction with the Semantic Definition Format (SDF) for Data and Interactions of Things (RFC 9880).
```

pulls.title: Turn `sdfRequired` into an array
pulls.author: JKRhb
pulls.body:
As pointed out by `sdfcheck` (thanks, @cabo!), the `sdfRequired` is currently used incorrectly in the draft (as it is only a simple string at the moment). The error resulted from a slight misinterpretation of the SDF base specification by me.

This PR turns wraps the value in an array, which resolves the problem.
